title: Fails on Windows when the user folder name includes spaces
body:
My user folder is at `C:\Users\John Doe`.

Running gource throws an error:
```
fatal: ambiguous argument 'Doe\AppData\Local\Temp\\gource-a16780': unknown revision or path not in the working tree.
Use '--' to separate paths from revisions, like this:
'git <command> [<revision>...] -- [<file>...]'
gource: failed to generate log file
Try 'gource --help' for more information.
```
and it creates an empty "John" file at `C:\Users\John`.

I'm on Windows 10.

title: Build fails with upcoming Boost 1.89.0
body:
In the upcoming Boost 1.89.0 release, Boost.System stub library has been removed (https://github.com/boostorg/system/commit/7a495bb46d7ccd808e4be2a6589260839b0fd3a3) which causes a configure error

```
checking for boostlib >= 1.46 (104600)... yes
checking whether the Boost::System library is available... yes
configure: error: Could not find a version of the Boost::System library!
```

since `libboost_system` won't be found at:
https://github.com/acaudwell/Gource/blob/8e96b12cd3014df8c920bae2b89eeadda6c8a073/m4/ax_boost_system.m4#L87

---

May need change in detection within ax_boost_system.m4 and/or some version specific logic in configure.ac

https://github.com/acaudwell/Gource/blob/8e96b12cd3014df8c920bae2b89eeadda6c8a073/configure.ac#L49-L50

---

EDIT: a workaround could be to pass `--with-boost-system=no`. A bit odd as Boost.System header-only lib exists but can avoid the detection logic until automatically handled.

title: Feature request: Single‚Äêslot captions (replace old caption instead of stacking)
body:
## Context and Problem

When using Gource with caption animations (`--seconds-per-day 0.05`, `--caption-duration 1.0`), multiple captions can overlap and stack vertically.

Wiki reference: https://github.com/acaudwell/Gource/wiki/Captions

## Desired Behavior

Gource should support a **single-slot captions** mode where any new caption replaces the currently displayed caption if it is still visible, ensuring at most one caption is shown at any time.

## Steps to Reproduce

1. Generate a log with multiple caption events close together.
2. Run:

   ```bash
   gource --seconds-per-day 0.05 \
          --caption-file captions.csv \
          --caption-duration 1.0 \
          --caption-offset 0 \
          path/to/repo
   ```

3. Observe that captions stack when intervals overlap.

## Proposed Solution

- Add a new option, e.g. `--single-slot-captions`, that enforces rollover behavior.

## Bounty

I am offering a **US$200** bounty (preferably paid in Bitcoin). Open to alternative payment methods‚Äîplease discuss before claim.

Thank you for considering this enhancement!

title: Migrate from GLEW to libepoxy or GLAD
body:
Hi,

we are currently trying to get rid of GLEW in Fedora as it isn't [maintained](https://github.com/nigels-com/glew/issues/416#issuecomment-2646570907) anymore. Also GLEW with the last release only supports GLX and not EGL.

There are two ways moving forward:
* Use [libepoxy](https://github.com/anholt/libepoxy)
* Use [GLAD](https://github.com/Dav1dde/glad/), or check out the [webservice for glad2](https://glad.sh/) to generate the files you need!

With both of them migration should be straight forward.

Thanks for considering!

title: Gource does not stop simulation when reading from STDIN
body:
I have a powershell script to generate a mp4 video using gource. The script looks like this:

```
$Command = @"
`$CombinedLog ``
| gource ``
    --load-config ./gource.config ``
    --path - ``
    --log-format custom ``
    --seconds-per-day $SecondsPerDay ``
    --output-ppm-stream - ``
| ffmpeg ``
    -i - ``
    -y ``
    -vcodec ppm ``
    -vcodec libx264 ``
    -preset veryfast ``
    -pix_fmt yuv420p ``
    -crf 1 ``
    -filter:v "setpts=PTS/2" ``
    -threads 0 ``
    -bf 0 ``
    $VideoOutput
"@

# Execute the command
if ($PSCmdlet.ShouldProcess($CombinedLog, "$Command")){
    Invoke-Expression $Command
}
```

Overall the script does what it should. The issue I have is that at the end of the `$CombinedLog`, the gource simulation does not terminate.
The reason I use a `$CombinedLog` is that I am merging multiple repositories.
Is there any way to tell gource that the stream is finished?
The stream currently consists of concatenated newline-separated lines in a single string.

title: Request - option to use author's timestamp
body:
I recently rebased the commits on my repository. Therefore all the commit's timestamp over 2 months now are at the same time. The committer's timestamp has changed, but not the author's timestamp (see [here](https://stackoverflow.com/a/2976598/11292068)). Gource uses the committer's timestamp which isn't always accurate.

Have the option to use the author's timestamp in the visualisation.

title: Update wiki for merging multiple repositories in Windows
body:
The wiki article to merge multiple repositories is only for UNIX based systems.

Here's how you handle this in Windows.

    gource --output-custom-log repo1.txt "repo1/filepath"
    gource --output-custom-log repo2.txt "repo2/filepath"
    type repo1.txt repo2.txt > combined.txt
    sort combined.txt > sortedcombined.txt

title: Advanced Styling and related bugs
body:
Our project's git repo is hooked up to gource to auto-generate a new video every day and display and auto-play it on a screen in front of the department. Here is how our setup looks based on my own project (https://github.com/FrostKiwi/Mirrorball), with the company's logo switched out for Github's:

https://github.com/acaudwell/Gource/assets/60887273/b82d11ad-ab0f-46a4-86a0-c7bdd831990f

Also this Gource Explainer plays every loop, appearing subtitles also generated with Gource's message feature:

https://github.com/acaudwell/Gource/assets/60887273/2f30119e-01c6-4690-ab17-1228a3c57a61

Setting these up with Gource, I came across a couple issues:

- To see all the people's faces independent of zoom, I set `--fixed-user-size`. However, this setting ignores the name above the avatar and changes distance of the text to the avatar, based on zoom level, which leads to this big gap and name overlapping the photo
- Just like with the logo, being able to specify an offset in the form of `0.0x0.0`, it would be great to have the same for time, because right now time can only be on top and to get it to the left this hacky workaround had to be used: `--date-format "                                                      %YÂπ¥%mÊúà%dÊó• %H:%MÊôÇ"`
- It would be great to have two more `logo` type overlay definitions: `Header` and `Footer`, to specify elements at the top and bottom of the screen. Right now the whole overlay is one big logo PNG, which makes it resolution dependent. I.e., a change in resolution or aspect ratio necessitates an update to logo png
- It would be great if the seed could influence the rest of the simulation, not just the colors. Sometimes the camera decides to rotate a horizontal tree vertically and have part of the graph cut-off by the screen edges. This happens randomly from time to time. It would be great to have one set seed, where the camera decided to rotate correctly and use that. Right now it seems gource is not deterministic in its simulation and camera movement

title: How to always show directory names
body:
I want to be able to have all directory names keep being displayed during the entire video, while having the file names appear and fade out as usual.

For this I've found two options

`----file-idle-time`

and 

`--filename-time`

Talking now only about names (not the nodes and vertices), with `--filename-time 0` files keep displayed during the entire video, but directories fade out. Whereas I want the opposite. I've looked in the manual and there doesn't seem to be an equivalent for directories like `--directory-name-time` and I haven't been able to understand what `--file-idle-time` actually does.

I have found Issue #215 which mentions `-hide filenames` but this completely turns off filenames and I would like to still see them a short time when the files first appear.

Basicall the wished behavior is the opposite of using `gource` with `--filename-time 0` only (which would be `files <persistent> directory <ephemeral>`) => 

```
file <ephemeral> directory <persistent>
```

Is this possible currently with gource ? If not, could you point me towards the bit of code that handles this if you don't mind so that I could try making a modification myself ?

Thanks in advance

title: How to use Gource on M1 device
body:
If anyone wants to run gource on a Macbook M1 chip device, You can refer to the following command

1. install deps

```bash
brew install pkg-config freetype2 pcre2 glow sdl2 sdl2_image boost glm autoconf
```

2. update configure

```bash
./configure --with-boost=/opt/homebrew/Cellar/boost/1.78.0_1/ CPPFLAGS="-I/opt/homebrew/Cellar/glm/0.9.9.8/include"
```

3. build gource

```bash
make
sudo make install
```

4. enjoy

The full process is documented [here](https://soulteary.com/2022/05/10/lets-talk-about-code-warehouse-visualization-with-gource.html) (translation required)


**The latest version 0.53 passed the test.**

title: Font size only applies to date and time and does not scale with resolution
body:
There are two problems with the font-size that both make the text too small to read on high resolutions such as 3840x2160 (4k):

1. The font size does not scale with resolution. So if I create a 4k video and upload it on YouTube and the users watch it in 720p, they cannot read anything.
2. The font size parameter --font-size only applies to the date and time at the top, so there is no way to manually increase the font size of the text in edges of the graph and the user names.

## Minimum Working Example

Use any repository and compare:

* gource -320x200 --font-size 1
* gource -3840x2160 --font-size 1

title: [feature] Add inter-user repel physics to rendering
body:
In large scale renderings, there is a tendency for users to clump together in the center. They are pulled away from the center due to the gravity of files they are working further out. It would be nice to have a parameter that would push users away from each other to reduce the amount of overlap.

One possible design is to modify `Gource::addUser` to inject a reference to the `users` map in the constructor of RUser:
https://github.com/acaudwell/Gource/blob/853554caa2a0c23661464fd1eef1988a146276f9/src/gource.cpp#L1018

Then modify `RUser::applyForceUser` and/or `RUser::applyForceAction`:
https://github.com/acaudwell/Gource/blob/853554caa2a0c23661464fd1eef1988a146276f9/src/user.cpp#L117

Here we can loop through the `users` map and compute manhatten distances between them. To simplify, the repel force can look at k=3 nearest neighbors to push away from them. We can play around with k and perhaps reduce it to 2 to see if a flocking effect can be achieved.

Thoughts?

title: [feature] Add way to specify --seconds-per-day for arbitrary date ranges
body:
This is kind of a crazy request that I'd like to work on and see what I can come up with. It's related to #238 but a more advanced way of specification.

My requirement is that I have a period from 1998 to 2007 that's pretty boring. When I pair it with music, it would be best if this period were compressed from the current runtime of 3:20s to 2:07s. In order for me to do that I would need to tell Gource to use a faster `--seconds-per-day` for that date range and another value for the date range after it.

Specifying this on the commandline is going to be difficult. One option is to have two parameters that are coupled with each other and that have comma separated specs. For example:

```
$ gource --seconds-per-day VAL1,VAL2 --seconds-per-day-dates DATE1,DATE2
```

Then in code, split these into two vectors. Make sure the size of them are the same, if not, throw error. If there's only one value in `--seconds-per-day`, then just implement current behavior.

Alternative 1: if it's too dangerous to reuse `--seconds-per-day`, define a new parameter.

Alternative 2: if command line specification is too hairy, another option is to specify this through a file just like `--caption-file`

Any preference on design?

title: [feature] Use filename font size setting for file key font size
body:
https://github.com/acaudwell/Gource/blob/93b5210e3809ff95b5ba50a13a84e42097573ae8/src/key.cpp#L166

The above code should use filename font size to grab the appropriately sized font rather than a hard coded value. When creating 4k videos using 3840x2160 resolution, the fonts become unreadable. To solve this, a user can pass --font-scale 2 in and get the desired effect. However, the file key does not reference the scaling parameter and so the file key is unreadable at 4k resolution. The idea will be to reuse the filename font size parameter for the key, rather than create another parameter for it. This would also then reference the font scale parameter.

title: Key item has no text
body:
# Overview

When creating a Gource video using the `--key` option when a file has no filetype, the unknown filetype will be given a background colour of white with no text

![image](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/5464272/88911770-3cf60d00-d256-11ea-8ef5-e9a166088ce1.png)

# Steps to Reproduce

Any repository that has files committed with no filetype extension should work.

1. Create a log file (e.g. `test_241.txt`) and add the following contents:
```
1584732701|Test User 1|A|/nofiletype
1596143177|Test User 1|A|/knownfiletype.file
```
2. Run Gource using the log file
```
gource test_241.txt --camera-mode overview --key --highlight-users --hide filenames --seconds-per-day 1 --auto-skip-seconds 1 -viewport 1280x720
```
## Expected Behaviour
Text to indicate a no extension filetype, like `Unknown filetype`

## Actual Behaviour
Blank box indicating unknown filetype

```yml
name: Gource
```

title: Support ISO 8601 datetimes (YYYY-MM-DD[Thh:mm[:ss]]) in custom log format and captions
body:
The [custom log format](https://github.com/acaudwell/Gource/wiki/Custom-Log-Format) and [captions](https://github.com/acaudwell/Gource/wiki/Captions) use Unix timestamps, which aren't user-friendly.

I propose that the reader check if "-" is in the time, and if so, interpret the time as an ISO 8601 format datetime per [W3C Note-datetime](https://www.w3.org/TR/NOTE-datetime). That is, "YYYY-MM-DD" optionally followed by "Thh:mm[:ss][offset]".

title: Feature Request: Aliases for users
body:
Sometimes the same user might have committed to the same source under multiple usernames. Maybe the username changed (got bored, got married, etc), or maybe they accidentally committed using the wrong account. Who knows? But it's possible.

It would be nice to be able to provide a username and a list of aliases that can all be grouped under that one username when displaying the video.

A user may be doing the work of two developers, but it's still off putting to actually see two developers show up. :)

title: What happened to user-scale?
body:

However, the latest build doesn't have the option - I get gource: unknown option user-scale=9.0.

Can this capability be easily restored?  My guess is that it disappeared by accident.

title: gource ppm output triggers ffmpeg invalid data error
body:
Since version 0.5 ffmpeg comes back with the errors/warnings 

`Stream #0: not enough frames to estimate rate; consider increasing probesize` 

(but increasing probesize doesn't help) and 

`Invalid data found when processing input`

 when using the command line 

```gource -1280x720 -o - | ffmpeg -y -r 60 -f image2pipe -vcodec ppm -i - -vcodec libx264 -preset ultrafast -pix_fmt yuv420p -crf 1 -threads 0 -bf 0 gource.mp4``` 

as used in [this](https://github.com/acaudwell/Gource/wiki/Videos) example. This also applies to WebM encoding and for the method where you first go via the raw (ppm) video. ffmpeg always fails at the same second mark in my input file so it seems there's something there which it doesn't like?


title: Making videos with --file-show-filter seems to blow up.
body:
Per the Videos wiki page, this works: 

```
gource -1280x720 -o - | ffmpeg -y -r 60 -f image2pipe -vcodec ppm -i - -vcodec libvpx -b 10000K gource.webm
```

If I add a filter though, it barfs:

```
gource -1280x720 --file-show-filter '.*driver.*' -o - | ffmpeg -y -r 60 -f image2pipe -vcodec ppm -i - -vcodec libx264 -preset ultrafast -pix_fmt yuv420p -crf 1 -threads 0 -bf 0 gource.mp4
```

The position of the `--file-show-filter` param doesn't change the outcome. The repo is https://github.com/flutter/flutter if that is important.

The barf? -->

```
[image2pipe @ 0x7fbcfa001600] Could not find codec parameters for stream 0 (Video: ppm, none): unspecified size
Consider increasing the value for the 'analyzeduration' and 'probesize' options
Input #0, image2pipe, from 'pipe:':
  Duration: N/A, bitrate: N/A
    Stream #0:0: Video: ppm, none, 60 tbr, 60 tbn, 60 tbc
Please use -b:a or -b:v, -b is ambiguous
Output #0, webm, to 'gource.webm':
Output file #0 does not contain any stream
```

title: "gource: failed to generate log file" when `showSignature` is set in .gitconfig
body:
Hello,
If the `.gitconfig` file contains the following:
```
[log]
        showSignature = true
```
and if some commits are signed, the log file does not have the right format, hence the following error:
```
gource: failed to generate log file
Try 'gource --help' for more information.
```

Enabling this option causes gource to use the time of the

commits are not corresponding to the order of the commits.

title: Enable TLS on gource.io
body:
Visiting https://gource.io/ leads to a certificate error, as GitHub serves a certificate only valid for GitHub subdomains.

As of May 1, GitHub supports TLS for custom domains by hosting sites on a CDN. This means [updating the DNS records for gource.io](https://blog.github.com/2018-05-01-github-pages-custom-domains-https/#configuring-your-domain) should be enough to enable TLS via Let‚Äôs Encrypt.

title: File extension key - Files without extension
body:
In the file extension key all files without an extension are grouped in a white entry without text. There should be at least an option to take the full filename as the extension when there is no extension. Example files are:
README
LICENSE
Makefile
Dockerfile
qmldir: http://doc.qt.io/qt-5/qtqml-modules-qmldir.html

related_commits.message:
Added file-extension-fallback to the configuration.

Enabling this option causes gource to use the filename
as the file extension if no extension is set or the
filename ends with a dot. As a result every file without
an extension has an own entry in the file extension key.
related_commits.author: Lars Schmertmann

title: Wrong handling of unexpected timestamps?
body:
We are working with a lot of people on a Mercurial project. The timestamps are not in ascending order because the timestamp represents the time of creation of the commit and not the time of push/publish. In some extreme cases the time of the new commit is 2 month before the last commit.

With this situation, I am not able to create a linear simulation. When I set seconds-per-day to 1, I would expect a simulation time of 90 seconds for a project running for 3 month. But when the commit, described above, is processed, the time jumps 2 month back, extending the simulation time by 60 seconds. During this 60 seconds nothing happens, because the next commit is 2 month in the future.
Setting auto-skip-seconds is not a valid option to solve this problem I think.

Gource should adjust the timestamp to something like "1 hour after the last commit". Maybe we can add an option so the user can control this time. But in general Gource should not jump back in the past.

related_commits.message:
Added no-time-travel to the configuration

Enabling this option causes gource to use the time of the
parent commit, if the time of a commit is in the past.
This allows a linear simulation, even if the time of the
commits are not corresponding to the order of the commits.
related_commits.author: Lars Schmertmann

title: Video recommendations on Wiki produce huge files
body:
https://github.com/acaudwell/Gource/wiki/Videos suggests a CRF of 1 and a preset of "ultrafast" for calling FFmpeg.

These parameters will produce files that are massively larger than they need to be - around 4 times the size for me.

https://trac.ffmpeg.org/wiki/Encode/H.264#FAQ suggests that a CRF of 17 is effectively lossless (and certainly looks so to me).  Processing with this, and a preset of "medium" gives me a file which is approximately a quarter the size of the one produced with the example command line.

Also, because a PPM file is massive, it's likely that the conversion will be constrained by disk speed in any case - the slowness of reading through the 43GB ppm file from my SSD meant that the FFmpeg CPU usage couldn't get above 50% (across all cores).  So there's not much point going for "ultrafast".

Could the wiki be updated?

title: -- Mac support ; building with macports howto (not an issue)
body:
Ports needed: 

```
sudo port install freetype
sudo port install giflib
sudo port install tiff
sudo port install jpeg
sudo port install libpng
sudo port install boost
sudo port install glew
sudo port install glm
sudo port install libsdl2
sudo port install libsdl2_image
sudo port install ffmpeg
```

SDL2_image patching if port broken:

```
mkdir -p /tmp/SDL2_image
pushd /tmp/SDL2_image
curl -O https://www.libsdl.org/projects/SDL_image/release/SDL2_image-2.0.3.tar.gz
tar -xzf SDL2_image-2.0.3.tar.gz
pushd SDL2_image-2.0.3
./configure --prefix=/opt/local
make
sudo make install
popd
popd
rm -rf /tmp/SDL2_image
```

Building gource:

```
mkdir -p /tmp/gource
pushd /tmp/gource
curl -O https://github.com/acaudwell/Gource/releases/download/gource-0.49/gource-0.49.tar.gz
tar -xzf gource-0.49.tar.gz
pushd gource-0.49
...

```

Voila!!

title: Add option to limit dirname display by directory depth
body:
Displaying all directory names in big trees clutters the screen. Using the option "--hide dirnames" removes all directory names. Neither of these extremes is what I usually want.

Instead, it would be great to have an option like "--max-dirname-depth" where one could specify the directory depth until where the directory names are shown. That way the top level directories could still be identified whereas the smaller, more dense parts of the tree are not covered by countless unreadable sub-directory names.

title: GLM 0.9.9.0 behaves incorrectly with Gource

I was testing `glm` update from 0.9.8.5 to 0.9.9.0 in FreeBSD, and it turned out that it breaks gource behavior - while with 0.9.8.5 it works well, with 0.9.9.0 the output becomes antsy and convulsive at some point - when new directories appear in repository, they start to jump left and right instead of smoothly distributing into usual flower-like structure. I can try to record a video if you cannot reproduce this.

Also, glm has hidden some experimental features by default, so gource now needs ` -DGLM_ENABLE_EXPERIMENTAL=1` in compiler flags.

title: Error when running inside submodule
body:
I often work with git repos that have multiple nested git submodules. I'm trying to write a script that builds on the instructions from https://github.com/acaudwell/Gource/wiki/Visualizing-Multiple-Repositories to combine the histories of the parent repo and all submodules. In the process of testing this, I discovered a strange behavior. When running gource inside a submodule, the result actually contains the changes of the parent repo, not the submodule.

I'm able to reproduce the issue with this simple script:
```bash
#!/bin/sh

set -ex

gource --help | head -n 1
git --version

TMP_DIR=$(mktemp -d)

cd $TMP_DIR
git init child
cd child
pwd
touch child.txt
git add child.txt
git commit -m 'Initial commit'

cd $TMP_DIR
git init parent
cd parent
pwd
touch parent.txt
git add parent.txt
git commit -m 'Initial commit'
git submodule add $TMP_DIR/child
git commit -m 'Add child submodule'

cd child
pwd
gource --output-custom-log gource.log
cat gource.log

cd $TMP_DIR/child
pwd
gource --output-custom-log gource.log
cat gource.log
```

In my case, this outputs:
```
+ gource --help
+ head -n 1
Gource v0.43
+ git --version
git version 2.7.4
+ mktemp -d
+ TMP_DIR=/tmp/tmp.INraelikKk
+ cd /tmp/tmp.INraelikKk
+ git init child
Initialized empty Git repository in /tmp/tmp.INraelikKk/child/.git/
+ cd child
+ pwd
/tmp/tmp.INraelikKk/child
+ touch child.txt
+ git add child.txt
+ git commit -m Initial commit
[master (root-commit) 98e5cd2] Initial commit
 1 file changed, 0 insertions(+), 0 deletions(-)
 create mode 100644 child.txt
+ cd /tmp/tmp.INraelikKk
+ git init parent
Initialized empty Git repository in /tmp/tmp.INraelikKk/parent/.git/
+ cd parent
+ pwd
/tmp/tmp.INraelikKk/parent
+ touch parent.txt
+ git add parent.txt
+ git commit -m Initial commit
[master (root-commit) b8be41b] Initial commit
 1 file changed, 0 insertions(+), 0 deletions(-)
 create mode 100644 parent.txt
+ git submodule add /tmp/tmp.INraelikKk/child
Cloning into 'child'...
done.
+ git commit -m Add child submodule
[master d154fb7] Add child submodule
 2 files changed, 4 insertions(+)
 create mode 100644 .gitmodules
 create mode 160000 child
+ cd child
+ pwd
/tmp/tmp.INraelikKk/parent/child
+ gource --output-custom-log gource.log
+ cat gource.log
1509756722|author|A|/parent.txt
1509756722|author|A|/.gitmodules
1509756722|author|A|/child
+ cd /tmp/tmp.INraelikKk/child
+ pwd
/tmp/tmp.INraelikKk/child
+ gource --output-custom-log gource.log
+ cat gource.log
1509756722|author|A|/child.txt
```

So you can see that while running this inside the `child` standalone repo, it outputs the correct:
```
1509756722|author|A|/child.txt
```
when run inside the `child` submodule of the `parent` repo, it outputs:
```
1509756722|author|A|/parent.txt
1509756722|author|A|/.gitmodules
1509756722|author|A|/child
```
which corresponds to the history of the `parent` repo. I would expect the same output, containing the changes of the `child` repo in both cases.

title: Race condition reading logs generated by other processes
body:
On Linux, at least, it would be relatively easy to lock the files Gource is reading (--path, --caption-file).  This is especially important when Gource loops and the logs are being rewritten by an external process.  Ideally, Gource and the external process could cooperate through a file lock.  Then Gource won't read an empty or incomplete file.

If there are no objections, I will plan to work on a PR for this.

title: [Feature Request] --start-date show the state of the repository before running through changes
body: We currently run out of several long lived repositories that have seen lots of changes over the course of their lives (oldest one was first started in 1998 and the youngest repository was started in 2001). Currently when I start up gource using the --start-date option it only shows files that are added/changed after that date and doesn't first graph the files/directories in the repository at that time. This means that files that are deleted from the repository flash up and then disappear again. It would be nice if the state of the repository was first graphed as it was just before that start date and then changes show up relative to the full tree.

title: Gource hangs in Git bash, requires pressing Enter
body:
When I execute `gource` in Git bash, it prints or does nothing and it looks like it's hang, although it just requires to press <kbd>Enter</kbd>:

    $ gource --help

Until I press <kbd>Enter</kbd>, the command doesn't do anything.

Although it depends on how Git bash is executed. If it's executed using `git-bash.exe` (`C:\Program Files\Git\git-bash.exe`), which is the default, used by for example SourceTree, it behaves as I described above. When executed using `bash.exe` (`"C:\Program Files\Git\usr\bin\bash.exe" --login -i`) it prints the help immediately as in plain Windows Console or Cygwin.

Git version: 2.12.0 64-bit

title: Date display doesn't take into account system locale
body:
The date display in the application seems to be using an English (United States) (or possibly "C") locale for the display of dates instead of the system's locale settings.

For example, using `--date-format "%x"` on a Windows English (United Kingdom) system displays the date/time as `MM/DD/YYYY` instead of the expected `DD/MM/YYYY`.

Likewise, the implementation-specific `--date-format "%#x"` (["Long date representation, appropriate to current locale."](https://msdn.microsoft.com/en-us/library/fe06s4ak.aspx)) displays dates as "Thursday, July 21, 2016" instead of the expected "21 July 2016".

It might simply be a case of calling `setlocale(LC_ALL, "")` or `setlocale(LC_TIME, "")` somewhere when the process starts up, but you may want to allow the locale to be configurable instead of always using the system locale.

Presently, we have to construct the date format manually to replicate the behaviour of the locale-aware strftime formats. For example, `--date-format "%d/%m/%Y"` and `--date-format "%d %B %Y"` for the locale-aware examples above.

This issue is not the end of the world, but it would be nice to not have to look into the system's regional settings to determine which flags will be needed to replicate the behaviour of the locale-aware formats (because sometimes it's hard to remember how your country formats its dates and times!).

title: [MacPorts] Gource fails to build on OS X 10.6.8
body:
Reference issue: https://trac.macports.org/ticket/50893

This is OS X 10.6.8, installing using MacPorts. This seems to be the relevant portion of the log (available on the MacPorts ticket);

title: [Feature request] loop through a period of history
body:
Currently, when `--loop` option is used, gource jumps to the start of the log at the end. I want an ability to loop to the position specified by `--start-position`, `-p` or `--start-date` options.

Although my use case doesn't need same behavior for `--stop-position` option, it seems reasonable to also take into consideration the end position options.

What I'm proposing is the following: change behavior of `--loop` option, so that

```
gource --start-position X --stop-position Y --loop
```

behaves like bash script

```
while true
do
    gource --start-position X --stop-position Y
done
```

but without overhead for reading log every time.

title: Improvement to the file-filter Option
body:
What about the said in [here](https://code.google.com/p/gource/issues/detail?id=126)?

The link sais:

```
Reported by skoobiedu@gmail.com, Apr 17, 2011
The file-filter option is OK, but I have over 400 extensions in one of my projects, and only want to show around 20 of them. It's extremely difficult to write a regex that filters out all but those 20. But, it's child's play to write a regex that matches them.

I suggest that the file-filter option be renamed to file-hide-filter, and that a new option be added called file-show-filter. So, if gource were run with this new option as shown:

gource --file-show-filter .+\.(c(c|pp|s(proj)?|xx)?|d(ll|sp)|exe|filters|h(pp)?|i(n(c|l)|pp)|lib|sln|vcx?proj)$

all of the following files will be shown: *.c, *.cc, *.cpp, *.cs, *.csproj, *.cxx, *.dll, *.dsp, *.exe, *.filters, *.h, *.hpp, *.inc, *.inl, *.ipp, *.lib, *.sln, *.vcproj, and *.vcxproj.

Of course, file-filter could be left as is for backward-compatibility. The new file-show-filter option would be easy to implement because it's the inverse of file-filter. Instead of removing the files that are matched, the files that aren't matched are removed.

Just my two cents.

- Jordan
```

title: README issues
body:
### Keyboard controls manual is not full

Many of the keys are not covered, and it's not always obvious what they do.

For example, `[` `]` - I think they change "elasticity", but I'm not sure.

`r` - show/hide first (?) level directories edges. `y` - show/hide all edges

`q` `w` `t` - show/hide some debug output.

`d` - change level at which directory names are shown.

`f` - cycle through "show filenames" "show only extensions" "hide filenames"
### Scales

It's not clear what is a "time scale" in gource. "user scale" changes sizes of avatars, which should be mentioned in manual too.
